content.description: This is an easy problem that is good for warming up your heel hooking prowess. Two jugs for a start and two feet under the "roof" lead to a right heel hook. From there two bomber wrap arounds on a block right in front of your face occupy your hands. From the wraps there are a few nice holds to the top, like I said, easy.
content.protection: sloped landing with various debris = a pad
content.location: Take the stairs to the normal problems (calm, local, etc.) but head right along the face for a few minutes. The route is found about 10 feet from a grouping of 4 trees right next to the rock face.

climbs.name: What's the Difference Between Jam and Jelly?

content.description:
SDS then combine face holds with perfect hand jams to ascend this aesthetic crack to the first ledge. 

  Downclimb or jump into the waiting arms of you spotters.
content.protection: Pads and spotters.
content.location: Obvious crack on the wall between the "Bison" problems and Thrutch and Wiese.

content.description:
SDS on the obvious rail in the streak, then climb bigger holds through easier moves to the first ledge. The crux is probably not dabbing on the first two moves. 

  Downclimb or jump into the waiting arms of you spotters.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter or two.
content.location: On the wide wall right of the Bison problems and left of Thrutch and Wiese.

content.description:
The Traverse of the Gods starts on the far left side of the wall and traverses rightward to finish on Thrutch and Wiese. Attempts have been made to continue the traverse across the long low roof, but each subsequent climber has been thwarted...much like those who attemped the Eiger Nordwand before its eventual first ascent.  

  As it stands now, though, the long traverse offers quite a pump and topping out on Thrutch and Wiese becomes a challenge in its own right.
content.protection: Stamina. Courage. Crash Pads.

content.description: Thrutch and Wiese climbs up the center of the face to the left of the long roof. This face is slightly overhanging and the holds are quite good. Top out. A sit start is possible but adds little difficulty.
content.protection: Pads

climbs.name: Those are Combines Kickin' Up That Dust

content.description:
Apologies to James McMurtry. This takes what I would consider to be the most "natural" and direct line up the face from the "Bison's Mouth". SDS from the "Mouth" and the righthand pocket(it actually helps) then take the path of least resistance straight up to the first ledge. 

  Downclimb or jump into the waiting arms of you spotters.
content.protection: Couple pads and some spotters, the landing is questionable.
content.location: Climber's left side of the lower face of the Pavilion Block, look for the obvious "Mouth" hold.

content.description: SDS with left hand in the little circle pocket of Bison Corposantics, work up to large flake fin with a variety of good holds to get to the top. Straight line up.
content.protection: One pad for rocks on landing.
content.location: Left side of pavilion block--right around the corner from the start of Traverse of the Gods. To the right of Bison Corposantics

content.description: This traverse starts on the far right hand side of the crag, just as you get to the bottom of the stone staircase. Start on large jug that is about chest height.  Traverse left past "Local on the Eights" staying low using the large shelf.  Choose your path moving left through "Calm Like a Bomb" (You can go high or low through this section). Continue traversing left under the steep roof using pockets and small crimps until you reach the more vertical face of "Mono Problem".  Get a good no-hands rest here and go left past the crack through the last 50 feet of easier climbing. End on the far left corner of the crag.  A serious pump-fest!
content.protection: A few pads are necessary to protect the crux under the steep roof.

content.description:
I don't know the real name of this route, so I call it Over My Head. 

  It is located right next to Harappan Civilization. It is to the right of the graffiti "Tumot Off." start right under the "Off" and work your way up to reach the obvious two-finger pocket. This is a blind move so good luck finding it. After you hit the pocket, work the roof and "top it out."  

  I haven't got this route yet but I know people who have.
content.protection: The landing for this route is also pretty bad. Better get some spotters and pads.

content.description:
Start sitting just to the right of the big face of Thrutch and Wiese and just to the left of the long low roof. Climb up the face using (you guessed it) a mono. 

  It is possible to continue into Thrutch and Wiese or forge your own way up the wall. Top out.
content.protection: Pads

content.description:
This is a pretty fun route that I call Local on the Eights. It is fairly easy but very cool.  

  When you walk down the stairs to get to the bouldering, it is one of the first routes.  

  It starts with a sit start, goes to the big ledge, and up to the little roof. After the roof go a couple moves more until a big ledge.
content.protection: Some pads and spotters wouldn't hurt.

content.description:
SDS on the obvious jug, then link the big, chalked-up jugs to the first ledge. 

  Downclimb or jump into the waiting arms of your spotters.
content.protection: Pads and spotters.
content.location: Just to the left of What's the Difference Between Jam and Jelly?.

content.description: Slightly overhanging arete. Start on large block and make some technical moves slightly right, then continue up the arete. Crux for me was the bottom section.
content.protection: 2 pads
content.location: to the right of Mono Problem. As most problems here, stop when you reach the large ledge and drop down.

content.description:
This is one of my favorite boulder problems at High Cliff. I don't know who the made the FA, but I call it Harappan Civilization.  

  It is located about 20 feet left of Calm like a Bomb. The climb starts where some graffiti is. It reads "Tumot off" or something like that.  

  Start on the white colored rock down and to the left of this graffiti. Work your way up and over the roof. It can just end when you are standing above the roof.
content.protection: The landing is pretty bad on this route. And because you are pulling the roof, a spotter and some pads are helpful.

content.description: Fun traverse. Start to the right of Calm Like a Bomb in the cave. Move out to the arete on a sloper, move to the giant rail and ride that to Local on the Eights. Gain the 2 crimps on the Local and make a big move out right to a jug. Swing over and finish up the slightly overhung face to the top of the ledge.
content.protection: 3-4 pads and spotters to move them for you.
content.location: to the right of Calm Like a Bomb in the cave.

content.description: Start low on a right hand good pocket and a left hand sidepull. Work your way up though good holds and hit a small hold at the lip and make your way to the better holds.
content.protection: A couple pads would be good for the larger rocks.
content.location: Just to the left of Calm Like a Bomb.

content.description: This isn't my problem so chime in if you have additional info.. This is cool because it's a vertical problem which is kinda rare at highcliff.  Start on the obvious start hold that looks like a frowning mouth, from there several variations are possible, work your way up to the juggy horizontal and then pull up to the first big ledge. You can either drop off from the ledge, traverse off left or top out the formation.
content.protection: Maybe a pad, can get by without one as the landing is very nice.
content.location: Just to the right of the pavilion block proper, on the wall right of the stairs when standing in front of Local on the Eights.

content.description:
The Campus Problem climbs up the center of the big roof. Start with holds above the roof and campus and throw to better holds higher. Shorter climbers may have to jump to the start holds. 

  The sit start has been a project for years. This would involve climbing through the roof using only a funny undercling bulb.
content.protection: Pads

content.description:
Walk down the steps to the east of the Redbird Statue and below the main pavilion area. The trail will take you to a huge detached block. Some good bouldering can be found on the downhill side of the block. 

  A blank roof crosses the right side of the wall. "Calm" climbs up a very overhanging prow that juts out from the right side of the wall, just right of the roof. Heel hooks and slaps lead to easier moves. The climb was topped-out on the first ascent, but this is not necessary as the top is tall, easy, and uninspiring.  

  "Calm" looks and climbs a lot like "The Buddha" at the Gunks.
content.protection: pads

content.description: SDS with left in Bison mouth and right in little circle pocket, same as Bison Corposantics. Work through sloper, mono pinch, flake, mono, ledges and out. This problem goes from bison head diagonal left to the top.
content.protection: Two pads for rocks on landing.
content.location: Left side of pavilion block--right around the corner from the start of Traverse of the Gods.

content.description: SDS low, with left hand in bison's mouth hold, which is a large slot, and the right in a small pocket. Work slight left, then up and right, through horn, sloper, mono, undercling, and then right on edges. Big move straight to the top.
content.protection: Two pads for the jagged rocky landing.
content.location: Left side of pavilion block--right around the corner from the start of Traverse of the Gods.

content.description: Start sitting on two good crimps and work your way up to the roof, reach out and gaston the golf ball hold and gain the lip into Campus Problem.
content.protection: Pads
content.location: This is a sit-start to Campus Problem.

content.description: Start sitting and matched on a left facing sidepull, climb up to the pockets under the roof and jump to a better pocket above the lip, climb up several more moves to a large jug at about the 15' mark. Hang and drop.
content.protection: Pads
content.location: Between Formidable Forecast and Big Man on Campus.

content.description: Starts on a good two hand block to the left of Harappan Civlization. (About 50 feet to the left of calm like a bomb) First move is a big one to a large horn 4 feet or so to the left. A series of pockets and crimps to the top out above mono problem.
content.protection: Probably a boulder pad or two...
content.location: Down hill side of the North Pavilion Block with the rest of the classics.

content.description:
About a gajillion years ago, a large, house-sized block detached from the main cliffband. On the downhill side of the block, the wall is steep, featured, and pretty good for bouldering. Most of the problems start with difficulty and get easier the higher you go. It's a good thing, as the wall is about 25 feet tall. 

  A roof splits the right side of the wall and presents the opportunity for some really hard problems. Most established problems start on either side of the long, low roof. The left side of the wall is quite tall and generally unsuitable for bouldering, though The Traverse of the Gods climbs across this section.  

  The leaf-filled corridor is also included in this area and can be found about 100 yards east of the block. The problems are shorter and provide high quality bouldering with good top outs.
